claim: Many cytokines that are produced by cancer cells also contribute to carcinogenesis.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification:
Several of the cited studies show that cancer cells synthesize cytokines (or cytokine-like secreted factors) and that these same molecules actively drive tumor-promoting processes such as proliferation, angiogenesis, immune evasion or metastasis.
• Paper 3: Breast‐cancer cells highly express VEGF, TGF-β1, thymidine phosphorylase, etc.; high VEGF levels are associated with poorer prognosis, indicating that tumor-derived VEGF and other cytokines foster disease progression.
• Paper 5: Breast-cancer cells with activated mTOR signaling up-regulate G-CSF, which recruits myeloid-derived suppressor cells and promotes tumor initiation; blocking G-CSF or MDSCs impairs tumor growth.
• Paper 7: Skin-tumor models show that autocrine VEGF produced by neoplastic epidermal cells is required for their own proliferation; deleting VEGF or its receptor FLT1 in tumor cells markedly delays tumorigenesis.
• Paper 4: Gastric-cancer exosomes carry HMGB1 (a pro-inflammatory cytokine-like mediator) that activates neutrophils, which in turn enhance gastric-cancer cell migration; silencing HMGB1 abolishes this effect.
• Paper 2 and Paper 9 further document tumor-derived IL-6, VEGF and other pro-inflammatory cytokines correlating with poor outcome or stimulating tumor-stroma interactions that increase invasiveness.
Together these findings demonstrate that many cytokines secreted by cancer cells themselves actively contribute to carcinogenesis, supporting the claim.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification:
Paper 6 shows that epidermal tumor cells over-produce the cytokine/ growth factor VEGF and that this tumor-cell–derived VEGF acts autocrinely to drive their own proliferation and is required for skin-tumor formation. When VEGF or its receptor Flt1 is deleted in the cancer cells, tumorigenesis is markedly delayed, demonstrating that the cytokine produced by the cancer cells itself promotes carcinogenesis.  
Paper 3 reports that gastric-cancer-cell–derived exosomes contain the pro-inflammatory mediator HMGB1; this tumor-cell–derived cytokine-like protein activates neutrophils via TLR4/NF-κB signalling, and the activated neutrophils in turn enhance gastric-cancer-cell migration. High HMGB1 expression in tumors correlates with poor patient prognosis, indicating that the cancer-cell-secreted factor contributes to tumor progression.  
Together, these studies provide direct experimental evidence that cytokines produced by cancer cells (e.g., VEGF, HMGB1) actively promote carcinogenesis, supporting the claim.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT
posthoc_result.justification: Several of the cited papers report that cytokines secreted by the cancer cells themselves actively drive tumor-promoting processes.  (1) Paper 7 shows that epidermal tumor cells make VEGF and require this autocrine VEGF signal, together with EGFR, to sustain their own proliferation and tumor formation, demonstrating a direct carcinogenic role of a tumor-cell–derived cytokine.  (2) Paper 8 demonstrates that activation of oncogenic mTOR signaling in mammary carcinoma cells up-regulates their production of G-CSF; the secreted G-CSF recruits myeloid-derived suppressor cells that, in turn, enhance tumor initiation—again establishing a carcinogenic function for a cytokine produced by the cancer cells.  (3) Paper 4 reports that higher expression of PD-ECGF (thymidine phosphorylase) in non-small-cell lung cancer cells correlates with increased angiogenesis and a more aggressive clinical course, indicating that this tumor-cell-derived cytokine contributes to malignant progression.  Together these studies provide direct experimental and clinical evidence that cytokines produced by cancer cells themselves promote tumor growth, angiogenesis, and initiation, thereby supporting the claim that many such cytokines contribute to carcinogenesis.

claim: Mutations in G-Beta protein GNB2 are present in many cancers, resulting in loss of interaction with G-alpha subunits and concomitant activation of AKT pathway.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Paper 9 reports recurrent somatic mutations in the G-beta proteins GNB1 and GNB2 across several human malignancies (myeloid and B-cell neoplasms and others). Functional analysis showed that these mutations disrupt the normal Gα–Gβγ interface, ‘disrupt[ing] Gα interactions with the Gβγ dimer.’ Expression of patient-derived GNB2 (and GNB1) mutants in hematopoietic cells produced factor-independent growth and malignancy, and the resulting signaling was suppressed by the dual PI3K-mTOR inhibitor BEZ235, demonstrating activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway. No other provided papers contradict or refute these findings. Thus the supplied evidence aligns with the claim that cancer-associated GNB2 mutations impair Gα binding and drive AKT-pathway activation.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 9 reports recurrent somatic mutations in the G-protein β subunits GNB1 and GNB2 across several human tumour types. The study shows that these mutations cluster at the interface that normally binds Gα subunits and experimentally demonstrate that the mutant Gβ proteins lose normal Gα interaction. Expression of patient-derived GNB2 (and GNB1) mutants in cells leads to constitutive downstream signalling that is sensitive to the dual PI3K-mTOR inhibitor BEZ235, indicating activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway. No other provided papers contradict or refute this observation. Thus, the evidence directly supports the claim that cancer-associated GNB2 mutations disrupt Gα binding and drive AKT-pathway activation.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 6 reports recurrent, cancer-associated mutations in the G-beta proteins GNB1 and GNB2. The study shows that these mutations map to the interface that normally binds G-alpha subunits and that they "disrupt Gα interactions with the Gβγ dimer," demonstrating loss of G-alpha binding. Expression of the mutant GNB proteins produced oncogenic signaling that could be suppressed in vivo with the dual PI3K-mTOR inhibitor BEZ235, indicating activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway. No other cited papers contradict or override these data. Thus the available evidence supports the claim that GNB2 mutations occur in multiple cancers, impair G-alpha interaction, and drive AKT-pathway activation.

claim: Primary pro-inflammatory cytokines induce secondary pro- and anti-inflammatory mediators.

naive_result.label: NOINFO

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 4 describes how the primary pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and TNF-α (often combined with IFN-γ) activate NF-κB and STAT-1 in pancreatic β-cells, resulting in the subsequent production of nitric oxide and various chemokines. These downstream products constitute secondary inflammatory mediators; some (certain chemokines) are pro-inflammatory, whereas others (e.g., NO can also have regulatory/anti-inflammatory effects depending on context). Paper 9 discusses the compensatory anti-inflammatory response syndrome, noting that the initial pro-inflammatory reaction is followed by induction of counter-regulatory anti-inflammatory mechanisms. Together these papers provide evidence that primary pro-inflammatory cytokines stimulate the generation of both additional pro- and anti-inflammatory mediators, which is consistent with the claim.

None provide experimental data showing primary cytokines inducing secondary mediators, so the supplied evidence is not relevant to confirm or refute the claim.

claim: During non-homologous end joining, the ligation step is not as tolerant of disrepairs and other distortions when joining 3' of strand breaks as compared to 5' strand breaks.

naive_result.label: NOINFO
naive_result.justification:
Paper 3 shows that when an abasic (damaged) nucleotide is situated close to the break, Ku’s dRP/AP-lyase acts efficiently on 5′-overhangs to prepare them for ligation, but is strongly suppressed on comparable 3′ termini because cleavage there would generate an α,β-unsaturated aldehyde that blocks DNA ligase IV.  The need to avoid creating this ligation-blocking structure indicates that the ligation step is less able to accommodate distortions on the 3′ side than on the 5′ side.

Paper 8 further indicates polarity-dependent requirements for end processing: double-strand breaks bearing 3′ overhangs with gaps require Pol 4-mediated filling before ligation, whereas 5′ overhangs of the same sequence can be ligated without this extra processing.  This difference demonstrates that the ligase readily joins distorted 5′ ends but needs additional correction for comparable 3′ ends, again implying lower tolerance at 3′ strand breaks.

Together these findings support the claim that, during non-homologous end joining, the ligation step is less tolerant of mispairs, damage, or structural distortions at 3′ termini than at 5′ termini.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification:
Paper 2 examines how abasic (dRP/AP) lesions at opposite strand polarities affect the last step of NHEJ. It shows that when the lesion is located close to a 5′ end, Ku’s dRP/AP-lyase efficiently removes the damage and the processed end can subsequently be ligated. In contrast, if the same type of damage lies near a 3′ strand terminus, Ku is largely inactive because excision would generate an α,β-unsaturated aldehyde that blocks the NHEJ ligase; hence the ligation step is far less able to accommodate distortions at 3′ termini than at 5′ termini.  
Paper 10 reaches a similar conclusion from a different angle: double-strand breaks carrying 3′ overhangs with gaps require Pol4-dependent processing before ligation, whereas breaks with equivalent 5′ overhangs are joined directly without this extra processing. This indicates that the ligase can tolerate structural irregularities on the 5′ side more readily than on the 3′ side.  
Together, these findings support the claim that, in NHEJ, the ligation step is less tolerant of damage or distortions at 3′ ends than at 5′ ends.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 6 directly compares how damaged nucleotides near the two different termini are handled during non-homologous end joining (NHEJ).  It shows that when an abasic (damaged) nucleotide is located close to a 5′ strand end, Ku’s 5′-dRP/AP lyase efficiently excises the lesion and the XRCC4-ligase IV complex can readily complete ligation.  In contrast, Ku is “less active near 3′ strand termini, where excision would leave a ligation-blocking α,β-unsaturated aldehyde,” indicating that the ligation machinery is far less able to accommodate or bypass distortions at 3′ ends.  Thus the ligation step of NHEJ is more tolerant of damage/distortion on the 5′ side of a break than on the 3′ side, which is exactly what the claim asserts.  The other cited papers discuss general NHEJ factors or unrelated topics and do not contradict this conclusion.

claim: Gastric lavage is an effective treatment for acute paraquat poisoning.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: The most directly relevant evidence (Paper 3) compared paraquat-poisoned patients treated with only gastric lavage and symptomatic care versus those receiving hemoperfusion. Mortality was far higher in the gastric lavage group (92.1%) than in the hemoperfusion group (42.9%), indicating gastric lavage alone was not effective. A single case report (Paper 4) describes survival with early digestive decontamination plus hemodialysis and antioxidants, but cannot attribute benefit specifically to gastric lavage. Other papers either address different toxins (Paper 1) or different therapies (Papers 5, 10) and do not provide supportive evidence for lavage. Overall, the available evidence contradicts the claim that gastric lavage is an effective treatment for acute paraquat poisoning.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: The only directly relevant comparative data (Paper 3) shows markedly higher mortality in paraquat-poisoned patients treated with only gastric lavage and supportive care (92.1%) compared with those receiving hemoperfusion (42.9%), indicating that gastric lavage alone is not an effective therapy. A single case report (Paper 9) mentions early digestive decontamination as part of a multimodal regimen in a survivor but does not isolate gastric lavage or establish its efficacy. Other papers either address different toxins (Paper 1 on organophosphorus pesticides) or focus on extracorporeal treatments/predictors and do not support gastric lavage effectiveness in paraquat poisoning. Overall, the evidence provided opposes the claim.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 2 (paraquat-specific) reports markedly higher mortality in patients who received only gastric lavage with symptomatic care compared to those receiving haemoperfusion (92.1% vs 42.9%), suggesting gastric lavage alone is not effective therapy for acute paraquat poisoning. No provided study demonstrates a clinical benefit of gastric lavage in paraquat poisoning. While Paper 1 addresses gastric lavage in organophosphorus pesticide poisoning (not paraquat), it also finds no high-quality evidence supporting effectiveness, further weakening the claim. Other paraquat papers focus on hemoperfusion/CVVH and do not support gastric lavage efficacy. Overall, the evidence refutes the claim that gastric lavage is an effective treatment for acute paraquat poisoning.

claim: Long - range chromatin interactions regulate transcription.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers provide direct experimental evidence that long-range chromatin interactions regulate transcription. Paper 1 (Pol II ChIA-PET) maps widespread promoter-promoter and enhancer-promoter interactions and shows that genes engaged in these interactions are active, transcribed cooperatively, and exhibit cell-specific expression patterns linked to cell-specific chromatin contacts. Paper 2 (3C at the H19/Igf2 locus) demonstrates that CTCF-dependent looping on the maternal allele blocks distal enhancer access to Igf2, leading to its silencing, while paternal contacts permit activation; mutating CTCF sites disrupts this regulation. Paper 6 shows that the H19 ICR has methylation-sensitive, CTCF-mediated enhancer-blocking activity that determines Igf2 expression, a classic example of long-range regulatory control. Additional architectural context from Paper 4 supports a pervasive framework of CTCF/cohesin-mediated interactions within topological domains. Together, these findings confirm that long-range chromatin interactions can and do regulate transcription.

overthinking_result.label: SUPPORT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 3 directly shows that RNA polymerase II–associated long-range, promoter-centered chromatin interactions correlate with active transcription, that interacting promoters can influence each other, and that cell-specific interaction patterns align with cell-specific transcription, indicating regulatory roles for long-range contacts. Paper 7 provides functional evidence: disrupting CTCF–cohesin interactions (key mediators of chromatin looping/insulation) alters expression of the imprinted IGF2-H19 locus, demonstrating that long-range chromatin architecture modulates transcription. Paper 6 further links widespread CTCF/cohesin-mediated interactions within topological domains to genome organization underlying transcriptional regulation. Paper 8 reviews mechanistic models for CTCF/cohesin in genome folding and transcriptional control. Together, these support the claim that long-range chromatin interactions regulate transcription.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 1 (ChIA-PET in human cells) maps widespread long-range promoter-promoter and enhancer-promoter interactions associated with RNA polymerase II and shows that genes engaged in these interactions are generally active, can influence each other, and that cell-specific interactions provide structural frameworks for cell-specific transcription. Paper 6 demonstrates that distal p53-bound enhancers physically interact with multiple genes to mediate long-distance p53-dependent transcriptional regulation and that eRNAs from these enhancers are required for efficient transcriptional enhancement. These provide direct experimental evidence that long-range chromatin interactions regulate transcription. Other papers are less directly relevant to long-range interactions.

claim: The loss of the TET protein functions may have dire biological consequences, such as myeloid cancers.

These data directly support that loss of TET function can lead to myeloid cancers. Additional context from Papers 6 and 7 shows broader oncogenic and developmental consequences of reduced TET/5hmC, consistent with the claim.

claim: CRP is not predictive of postoperative mortality following Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) surgery.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: Paper 1 (CABG-only cohort, n=914) found that higher preoperative CRP predicted greater long-term, all-cause postoperative mortality after primary, nonemergent CABG: HR 2.50 (95% CI 1.22–5.16) for CRP 3–10 mg/L and HR 2.66 (1.21–5.80) for CRP >10 mg/L vs <1 mg/L. Paper 3 (cardiac surgery, including CABG) showed higher in-hospital postoperative mortality with elevated preoperative CRP (8.2% vs 3.4%; OR 2.61, p=0.02) and identified elevated CRP as an independent risk factor for mid-term survival. These findings indicate CRP is predictive of postoperative mortality following CABG/cardiac surgery, contradicting the claim. Other papers are not directly relevant to CABG postoperative mortality.

overthinking_result.label: CONTRADICT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 1 (CABG-only cohort) shows preoperative CRP ≥3 mg/L independently predicts higher long-term, all-cause mortality after CABG (HR 2.50 for 3–10 mg/L; HR 2.66 for >10 mg/L). Paper 4 (cardiac surgery, including CABG) shows higher preoperative CRP is associated with increased in-hospital postoperative mortality (OR 2.61). These findings indicate CRP is predictive of mortality after CABG/cardiac surgery, contradicting the claim.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 2 directly shows that in primary, nonemergent CABG patients, higher preoperative CRP predicts greater postoperative (long-term) all-cause mortality: CRP 3–10 mg/L and >10 mg/L were associated with increased mortality (HR 2.50 [1.22–5.16], P=0.01; HR 2.66 [1.21–5.80], P=0.02). Paper 3 (cardiac surgery, including CABG) found higher preoperative CRP associated with higher in-hospital mortality (8.2% vs 3.4%; OR 2.61, P=0.02) and worse mid-term survival. These findings refute the claim that CRP is not predictive of postoperative mortality following CABG. Other papers are not specific to CABG mortality or are unrelated.

claim: ATM and Rad3 related protein have no role in sensing DNA damage.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers show ATM and ATR (Rad3 related) function in sensing and signaling DNA damage. Paper 10 explicitly reviews how ATM/Tel1 and ATR/Mec1 sense and signal DNA double-strand breaks; Paper 1 notes replication stress triggers ATR activation leading to checkpoint signaling; Papers 2 and 4 show ATR-dependent Chk1 activation during replication stress; Paper 5 shows endogenous activation of ATM at replication-associated damage sites. These findings directly oppose the claim that ATM and ATR have no role in sensing DNA damage.

overthinking_result.label: CONTRADICT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 5 explicitly states that replication stress (a form of DNA damage/perturbation) triggers activation of ATR, leading to phosphorylation of RPA32 and Chk1-dependent checkpoint activation. Inhibition of ATR reproduces checkpoint defects, demonstrating ATR’s upstream sensing/response role to DNA damage. Paper 6 (review) further supports that the DDR is activated by sensor kinases like ATM/ATR across the cell cycle. Therefore, the claim that ATR (ATM and Rad3 related protein) has no role in sensing DNA damage is refuted by the provided evidence.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 1 shows that DNA damage activates ATM via Cdk5-dependent phosphorylation, which is required for ATM autophosphorylation and kinase activation, driving DNA damage signaling (affecting p53 and H2AX). Paper 2 reports strong enrichment of phosphorylated ATM at telomeres concomitant with induction of a DNA damage response, indicating ATM engagement in damage signaling. These findings demonstrate a role for ATM in sensing/signaling DNA damage, contradicting the claim. While ATR (ATM and Rad3-related) is not directly addressed, the claim that both ATM and ATR have no role is falsified by the clear evidence for ATM.

claim: Oxidative DNA damage activates STING signalling.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT

Paper 8 demonstrates that oxidized mitochondrial DNA released during NETosis is interferogenic and, when administered to mice, drives type I interferon signaling via a STING-dependent pathway. Together, these provide direct experimental evidence that oxidative DNA damage can activate STING signaling. Other papers either discuss DNA sensing mechanisms (Paper 2) or oxidative stress without linking to STING (Papers 3–7, 9–10) and do not contradict the claim.

Paper 6 demonstrates that DNA containing the oxidative lesion 8-hydroxyguanosine resists TREX1 degradation and thereby potentiates STING-dependent cytosolic DNA sensing; oxidized DNA occurs physiologically during ROS exposure and NET formation and drives IFN-associated pathology. Other papers provide background on STING activation by DNA but are not essential to the claim. No provided paper contradicts this.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT

Other provided papers do not contradict or materially inform this specific claim.

claim: 1-1% of colorectal cancer patients are diagnosed with regional or distant metastases.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT

claim: Helminths interfere with immune system control of macrophages activated by IL-4 favor Mycobacterium tuberculosis replication.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Paper 1 shows that helminth infection (Nippostrongylus brasiliensis) increases M. tuberculosis burden via the IL-4Rα pathway, leading to accumulation of alternatively activated (IL-4–driven) macrophages. IL-4Rα-deficient mice are more resistant and have fewer AAMs, and adoptive transfer experiments implicate macrophage IL-4R signaling directly in heightened susceptibility. Paper 6 provides a mechanistic basis: IL-4/IL-13 inhibit autophagy-mediated killing of intracellular M. tuberculosis in macrophages, thereby favoring bacterial persistence/replication. Together, these data support the claim that helminth-induced IL-4–activated macrophages impair immune control and promote M. tuberculosis replication.

overthinking_result.label: SUPPORT

Co-infected IL-4Rα−/− mice had reduced AAM accumulation and improved control of Mtb, and adoptive transfer of wild-type (IL-4Rα–competent) macrophages into IL-4Rα−/− mice increased Mtb burden, indicating a macrophage-intrinsic IL-4R pathway that favors Mtb persistence/replication. Other papers provided do not address helminth–IL-4–macrophage interactions with Mtb and do not contradict this finding.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 5 shows that helminth infection (Nippostrongylus brasiliensis) induces a Th2 environment that engages the IL-4Rα pathway, accumulates alternatively activated (IL-4-driven) macrophages in the lung, and increases M. tuberculosis burden. Co-infected IL-4Rα−/− mice control Mtb better, and adoptive transfer of wild-type (IL-4Rα+) macrophages into IL-4Rα−/− mice increases Mtb load, indicating a macrophage-intrinsic IL-4R effect. Paper 2 mechanistically supports this by showing IL-4/IL-13 inhibit autophagy and autophagy-mediated killing of intracellular M. tuberculosis in murine and human macrophages. Together, these data indicate helminth-induced IL-4 signaling in macrophages interferes with antimicrobial control and favors M. tuberculosis replication.

In differentiating cells, E2F1-3 function with Rb as repressors to facilitate cell-cycle exit. Thus, the anti-apoptotic/survival role of activator E2Fs is present in progenitor cells and is not limited to terminally differentiated cells. claim: De novo assembly of sequence data has shorter contigs than unassembled sequence data.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO

Paper 1 discusses assembly fragmentation due to GC bias (shorter contigs under strong bias) but not relative to unassembled data. Papers 2 and 4 report de novo assemblies without such a comparison. posthoc_result.label: NOINFO

Paper 1 notes factors that can fragment assemblies (e.g., GC bias) but also shows this can be rescued with more data, not that assembled contigs are shorter than unassembled reads. The remaining papers are unrelated to contig length or de novo sequence assembly. Thus, the claim that de novo assembly yields shorter contigs than unassembled sequence data is contradicted by the relevant evidence.

claim: Increased conversion of PGE 2 to PPARy ligand 15-ket-PGE 2 causes accumulation of PGE.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: Paper 1 shows that 15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase (15-PGDH) catalyzes the degradation of PGE2 to 15-keto-PGE2. When 15-PGDH is down-regulated, PGE2 degradation decreases and PGE2 accumulates in tissues. This implies the opposite of the claim: increased conversion to 15-keto-PGE2 would lower, not increase, PGE2 levels. Paper 3 identifies 15-keto-PGE2 as a PPARγ ligand but does not support that increased conversion causes PGE accumulation.

overthinking_result.label: CONTRADICT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 1 shows that 15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase (15-PGDH) enzymatically converts PGE2 to its metabolite 15-keto-PGE2 (a PPARγ ligand), i.e., this conversion represents PGE2 degradation. Down-regulation or genetic disruption of 15-PGDH reduces this conversion and is associated with elevated PGE2 levels, indicating that decreased (not increased) conversion leads to PGE2 accumulation. Paper 6 identifies 15-keto-PGE2 as an endogenous PPARγ ligand and reports reduced 15-keto-PGE2 in Cftr-deficient tissues, consistent with diminished conversion, but provides no evidence that increasing conversion causes PGE2 accumulation. Together, the evidence indicates that increased conversion to 15-keto-PGE2 would lower PGE2, contradicting the claim.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: Only Paper 1 is relevant to PGE2/15-keto-PGE2 and reports reduced amounts of the PPARγ ligand 15-keto-PGE2 in Cftr-deficient tissues. It provides no data on increased conversion of PGE2 to 15-keto-PGE2 or on resulting accumulation of PGE2. The other papers do not address PGE2 metabolism or 15-keto-PGE2. Therefore, the provided evidence does not confirm or refute the specific claim.

claim: The morphology change from large white adipocytes to small brown adipocytes is a sign of decreased energy expenditure potential in white adipose tissue.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers show that the transition (browning) from white adipocytes to brown/beige adipocytes is associated with increased, not decreased, energy expenditure. Paper 1 reports WAT browning elevates UCP1 and increases energy expenditure in cachexia. Paper 2 demonstrates robust UCP1-independent thermogenesis in beige fat via SERCA2b-mediated Ca2+ cycling. Paper 4 shows activating human brown adipose tissue increases whole-body energy expenditure. Paper 6 reviews that brown fat activation/browning raises energy expenditure and improves metabolism. Paper 8 states brown adipocytes dissipate energy whereas white adipocytes store it. Collectively, these findings contradict the claim that the morphological change toward small brown adipocytes indicates decreased energy expenditure potential.

overthinking_result.label: CONTRADICT
overthinking_result.justification: Multiple papers show that the switch from white to brown/beige adipocytes (browning) increases thermogenic capacity and energy expenditure, not decreases it. Paper 1 explicitly reports that WAT browning with increased UCP1 expression leads to increased energy expenditure in cancer cachexia. Paper 2 shows activating human brown fat increases whole-body energy expenditure. Paper 3 reviews that brown fat activation and WAT browning raise energy expenditure and promote a negative energy balance. Paper 6 demonstrates robust thermogenesis in beige fat (even UCP1-independent), indicating higher energy expenditure potential. Thus, the morphological change toward brown/beige adipocytes signifies increased, not decreased, energy expenditure potential.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT
posthoc_result.justification: Multiple papers show that the transition (browning) from white to brown/beige adipocytes increases thermogenic capacity and energy expenditure, not decreases it. Paper 1 demonstrates that WAT browning elevates UCP1 and energy expenditure in cachexia. Paper 2 shows activation of brown adipose tissue increases whole-body energy expenditure in humans. Paper 3 reviews that brown fat activation and WAT browning raise energy expenditure. Paper 4 states brown adipocytes dissipate energy whereas white store it, and browning is linked to thermogenic programs. Papers 5–7 further link catecholamine-driven browning to increased thermogenic gene expression and functional uncoupling. Therefore, the claimed morphology change indicates increased, not decreased, energy expenditure potential.

claim: r-protein chaperones are found in complexes with their r-protein binding partners.

overthinking_result.label: SUPPORT

Paper 5 shows an RNA-independent interaction between the chaperone B23/NPM and ribosomal protein S9, with B23 storing and protecting RPS9 in the nucleolus, further supporting that r-protein chaperones form complexes with their r-protein partners. Other papers are not directly relevant to this claim.

It facilitates nucleolar storage and protection of RPS9, implying a chaperoning role for a ribosomal protein and demonstrating that an r-protein chaperone is found in complex with its ribosomal protein binding partner. The other papers do not provide relevant counter-evidence.

The other papers concern microtubule binding (dynein, LRRK2) or amyloid biology (Aβ, APOE, CD33) but do not link MT-binding domains to amyloid formation. These residues lie within tau’s microtubule-binding repeat region, indicating that the microtubule-binding domain itself forms the amyloid core and drives aggregation in tau. The other papers do not address amyloid formation by microtubule-binding domains and do not contradict this. Thus, there is supportive evidence (in the tau system) for the claim.

claim: The deregulated and prolonged activation of monocytes has deleterious effects in inflammatory diseases.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Paper 3 shows that reduced KLF2 (a negative regulator of monocyte activation) leads to increased recruitment and proinflammatory activation of monocytes, with more severe arthritis and greater cartilage/bone damage—directly linking dysregulated monocyte activation to deleterious outcomes in an inflammatory disease. Paper 6 demonstrates that human monocytes can drive IL-1β-mediated immunopathology via an alternative inflammasome pathway, supporting a role for monocyte activation in harmful inflammation. Paper 9 indicates that genetic variants increasing expression of the TLR negative regulator TOLLIP reduce proinflammatory cytokines and sepsis risk, implying that insufficiently regulated innate (monocyte-related) activation worsens disease. Together, these findings support the claim that deregulated (and, in chronic models, prolonged) monocyte activation has deleterious effects in inflammatory diseases.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 2 shows that reduced KLF2, a brake on myeloid (including monocyte) proinflammatory activation, exacerbates responses in acute and subacute inflammatory models, and emphasizes that unchecked myeloid activation causes collateral tissue damage. Paper 9 identifies monocytes as key subsets recruited to inflamed tissues, underscoring their role in inflammatory pathology and as therapeutic targets. Paper 4 demonstrates that persistent immune activation worsens colitis severity, supporting the concept that prolonged immune activation is deleterious, though not monocyte-specific. Together, these data align with the claim that deregulated/prolonged monocyte-lineage activation contributes to harmful outcomes in inflammatory diseases.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: Across the provided papers, none present direct evidence that deregulated and prolonged activation of monocytes specifically causes deleterious effects in inflammatory diseases. Paper 2 shows KLF4 is essential for inflammatory monocyte differentiation but does not link prolonged monocyte activation to harm. Paper 6 implicates macrophages (monocyte-derived) in COPD pathogenesis but does not address prolonged monocyte activation per se. Paper 1 shows persistent immune activation worsens colitis, but focuses on T cells and general cytokines, not monocytes. Paper 3 indicates prolonged TLR3 activation in macrophages suppresses HIV replication, which is not deleterious. The remaining papers concern other inflammatory aspects without monocyte-specific prolonged activation data. Therefore, the specific claim is not directly supported or refuted by the provided evidence.

Paper 1 reports cold-induced browning of white fat (a "brite" transcription signature), indicating recruitment toward a brown phenotype. Paper 4 shows cold-induced recruitment of beige adipocytes in WAT (with Pdgfrβ+ mural cells contributing after prolonged cold). Paper 7 (review) states prolonged cold exposure induces browning of white adipose tissue and expands/activates brown fat. Paper 2 demonstrates cold-induced, UCP1-dependent thermogenesis, consistent with increased BAT activation. No provided paper reports a reduction of BAT recruitment with cold exposure.

claim: Glucose restriction to 0.05% reduces RLS (replicative life span) by 20-40% in S. cerevisiae.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: Multiple provided papers report that calorie or glucose restriction extends, not reduces, replicative lifespan (RLS) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Paper 1 shows lifespan extension by calorie restriction requiring SIR2/NAD. Paper 2 explicitly states that limiting glucose extends yeast lifespan, linking the effect to increased respiration. Paper 3 demonstrates that calorie restriction extends lifespan even independently of Sir2. None of the papers provide evidence that 0.05% glucose reduces RLS by 20–40%; most other papers are not directly about RLS under glucose restriction. Therefore, the claim is contradicted by the relevant evidence.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: Papers 5 and 7 report that calorie/glucose restriction in Saccharomyces cerevisiae extends replicative lifespan, not reduces it. Paper 5 shows lifespan extension by limiting glucose (via increased respiration), and Paper 7 shows lifespan extension by calorie restriction requiring SIR2 and NAD. None of the provided papers present data that 0.05% glucose reduces RLS by 20–40%; the direction of effect reported is opposite to the claim. Other papers listed are not directly about S. cerevisiae RLS under specific glucose percentages.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT
posthoc_result.justification: Multiple provided papers report that calorie/glucose restriction extends (not reduces) replicative lifespan in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Paper 1 shows lifespan is extended by limiting glucose and increasing respiration. Paper 7 explicitly demonstrates Sir2-independent life span extension by calorie restriction. Paper 10 shows life-span extension by calorie restriction requiring NAD/SIR2. None of the papers provide evidence of a 20–40% reduction in RLS at 0.05% glucose; instead they document extension under glucose restriction.

claim: Mice defective for deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) polymerase I (polI) reveal increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation (IR).

naive_result.label: NOINFO
naive_result.justification: None of the provided papers examine mice defective for DNA polymerase I (polI) or their response to ionizing radiation. The references discuss other polymerases (pol eta, pol beta, pol mu, pol lambda) in contexts such as UV sensitivity, NHEJ-mediated DSB repair, or cell line responses to IR, but not polI in mice. Relevant polymerases discussed include Pol β (overexpression in CHO cells increases IR sensitivity) and Pol λ (dominant-negative in mammalian cells increases IR sensitivity), but not Pol I in mice. Other papers address IR effects or DNA damage responses unrelated to Pol I. Therefore, the evidence does not address the specific claim.

claim: miRNAs regulate a unique suite of mRNAs to maintain homeostasis in cells.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers show that individual miRNAs bind specific sets of mRNAs and that this regulation underlies normal cellular function and stability. Paper 1 maps thousands of miRNA–3'UTR interactions in B cells, demonstrating that miRNAs (including viral and host) coordinately target suites of transcripts involved in immunity, survival, and proliferation. Paper 2 shows miR-21 directly represses IL-12p35, modulating immune balance. Paper 4 demonstrates miR-22 targets multiple pro-apoptotic and disease-related mRNAs to promote neuronal viability, consistent with homeostatic control. Paper 5 integrates miRNA and mRNA data in hematopoietic progenitors, validating that miRNAs hold differentiation programs in check—key for cellular homeostasis—and shows functional effects of miR-155. Paper 8 shows that loss of ADAR1 reduces global miRNA levels and alters target gene expression, indicating miRNA regulation is required for normal gene expression patterns. Paper 9 identifies a feedback loop where miR-71 modulates Argonaute and global miRNA abundance; disrupting it causes widespread mRNA dysregulation during aging, highlighting miRNA roles in maintaining expression homeostasis. Paper 10 links miRNA dysregulation with altered target protein levels in metastasis, reinforcing that miRNAs govern specific gene sets. Collectively, these findings support that miRNAs regulate distinct suites of mRNAs to sustain cellular homeostasis.

overthinking_result.label: SUPPORT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 5 explicitly proposes that each cell type has a unique miRNA milieu that dampens expression of thousands of mRNAs to achieve more uniform (homeostatic) gene levels within that cell type. Broad targeting is supported by Paper 6, which experimentally maps thousands of miRNA–mRNA interactions in cellular 3'UTRs, and by Paper 9, which shows individual miRNAs can regulate multiple transcripts and are recycled for multiple-turnover regulation. Specific regulatory examples (e.g., miR-21 repressing IL-12p35; Paper 4) and correlations between miRNA dysregulation and target protein changes (Paper 2) further illustrate miRNA-directed control of mRNA suites. Essentiality of miRNA processing for normal function (Paper 3) and cell-type–restricted miRNA expression (Paper 10) reinforce the role of miRNAs in maintaining cellular homeostasis via regulation of distinct mRNA sets.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 6 provides direct evidence that a specific miRNA (miR-92a) post-transcriptionally regulates the mRNA of KLF2, a key transcription factor for endothelial function, and that flow-dependent downregulation of miR-92a increases KLF2 to maintain endothelial homeostasis; in vivo delivery of miR-92a impairs flow-mediated vasodilation. This demonstrates miRNA-mediated regulation of a defined mRNA target to preserve cellular homeostasis. Paper 10 further supports miRNA specificity by showing miR-671 targets a circular antisense RNA to modulate CDR1 mRNA levels, illustrating miRNA-driven, target-selective control of gene expression. Paper 8 shows miRNA clusters can reprogram cell state by regulating broad gene networks, consistent with miRNAs controlling suites of mRNAs. Collectively, the evidence aligns with the claim.

claim: Glycan adaptation is rarely observed in the B-cell repertoire.

naive_result.label: NOINFO
naive_result.justification: None of the provided papers present data on the frequency of glycan adaptation within the B-cell repertoire. Most papers address T-cell selection/tolerance (Paper 1, 9), transcriptional regulation and chromatin (Paper 2), neutrophil calcium signaling (Paper 3), vaccine-induced immunity broadly (Paper 4), bacterial TAL effectors (Paper 5), pre-BCR selection without glycan focus (Paper 6), antigen relay and affinity maturation mechanics (Paper 7), limited SHM in TG2-specific autoantibodies (Paper 8), and HIV viral glycan epitope evolution (Paper 10). The only glycan-related content (Paper 10) concerns viral glycan shifts and glycan-dependent antibody epitopes, not the prevalence of glycan adaptation in B-cell repertoires. Thus, the claim is not addressed by the evidence.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: None of the provided papers assess the frequency of glycan adaptation within the B‑cell repertoire. The most relevant articles (Papers 6, 7, and 9) discuss HIV Env glycan evolution and glycan-dependent antibody epitopes, focusing on viral adaptation and bnAb lineages, not on how often B cells adapt to glycans across the repertoire. The remaining papers address unrelated topics (centromeres, progenitors, Alzheimer’s models, T-cell responses, antigen relay, infant cardiorespiratory control). Therefore, there is no direct evidence to confirm or refute the claim.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: None of the provided papers directly assess how often glycan adaptation occurs within the B-cell repertoire. Paper 9 discusses evolution of an HIV glycan-dependent epitope and the emergence of glycan-dependent broadly neutralizing antibodies in a minority of infected individuals, but this addresses viral glycan evolution and a specific antibody response rather than the general frequency of glycan adaptation within B-cell repertoires. Other papers focus on T-cell repertoire, dendritic cell glycan recognition, transcription factors, or non-glycan aspects of B-cell development and autoimmunity. Thus, the claim is not substantiated by the cited evidence.

claim: Immune responses result in the development of inflammatory Th17 cells and anti-inflammatory iTregs.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers show that immune responses give rise to proinflammatory Th17 cells and anti-inflammatory induced Tregs (iTregs). Paper 3 explicitly defines Th17 as proinflammatory and FoxP3+ Tregs as anti-inflammatory, and demonstrates induction of FoxP3 (iTreg) while inhibiting Th17 differentiation in response to retinoic acid. Paper 1 shows in an autoimmune arthritis model that retinal reduces Th17 cells and increases FoxP3+ Tregs, indicating reciprocal development during immune responses. Paper 5 demonstrates that bacterial infection induces regulatory CD4+ T cells that suppress colitis via IL-10, consistent with anti-inflammatory iTregs arising in response to immune stimuli. Paper 8 further supports the inflammatory role of Th17 by showing TLR-activated B cells suppress Th17-driven inflammation in EAE. Together, these data support the claim.

overthinking_result.label: SUPPORT
overthinking_result.justification: Paper 1 states that during TCR activation in a cytokine milieu (i.e., an immune response), naive CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th17 and iTreg lineages. Paper 6 explicitly characterizes Th17 cells as proinflammatory IL-17–producing cells and FoxP3+ Treg cells as anti-inflammatory, and shows immune-relevant modulation of their differentiation by retinoic acid. Paper 3 provides mechanistic evidence that the PI3K–Akt–mTORC1–S6K axis controls Th17 differentiation, supporting their development during immune activation. Paper 9 notes RORα as a switch governing mutually exclusive Th17 vs Treg generation tied to harm/protection balance. Together, these data support that immune responses drive development of inflammatory Th17 cells and anti-inflammatory iTregs.

posthoc_result.label: SUPPORT
posthoc_result.justification: Paper 4 shows that IL-1R signaling via BCAP–PI3K–mTOR drives differentiation of pathogenic (inflammatory) Th17 cells. Paper 6 explicitly states Th17 cells are proinflammatory and FoxP3+ Tregs are anti-inflammatory, and demonstrates that retinoic acid induces FoxP3 in CD4+ T cells (iTreg induction) while inhibiting Th17 polarization. Paper 10 further confirms reciprocal regulation in vivo: retinal increases FoxP3+ Tregs and reduces IL-17–producing T cells, ameliorating inflammatory arthritis. Together, these data support that immune responses can generate inflammatory Th17 cells and anti-inflammatory induced Tregs.

claim: NAC destabilizes NO to increase the effect of contrast agents on renal functions.

naive_result.label: CONTRADICT
naive_result.justification: The evidence shows that N-acetylcysteine (NAC) does not destabilize nitric oxide (NO) nor increase the harmful effects of contrast agents on renal function. Instead, NAC attenuates contrast-induced intrarenal vasoconstriction and increases intrarenal NO and PGE2 (Paper 6), and multiple clinical trials demonstrate NAC reduces contrast-induced deterioration in renal function (Papers 9 and 10). None of the provided papers indicate NAC destabilizes NO; some even show NAC is protective. Therefore, the claim is contradicted by the evidence.

overthinking_result.label: CONTRADICT
overthinking_result.justification: The provided evidence shows that N-acetylcysteine (NAC) mitigates, rather than enhances, contrast-induced renal dysfunction and is associated with increased, not destabilized, intrarenal nitric oxide (NO). In a rat model of contrast-induced nephropathy, NAC significantly attenuated intrarenal vasoconstriction and increased intrarenal NO and PGE2 levels (Paper 6). Clinically, prophylactic NAC reduced the incidence of contrast-induced rises in serum creatinine and even lowered mean creatinine post-contrast, indicating protection of renal function (Paper 8). No paper shows NAC destabilizing NO; the other papers address NO biology without linking NAC to NO destabilization. Thus, the claim that NAC destabilizes NO to increase the effect of contrast agents on renal functions is contradicted by the evidence.

posthoc_result.label: CONTRADICT
posthoc_result.justification: The cited studies show NAC protects against, rather than enhances, contrast-induced renal dysfunction, and does not destabilize NO. Paper 1 and Paper 2 (randomized clinical trials) demonstrate NAC reduces the incidence of contrast-induced nephropathy and improves renal function metrics after contrast exposure. Paper 3 (rat model) shows NAC attenuates contrast-media–induced renal vasoconstriction and increases intrarenal NO and PGE2, opposing the idea that NAC destabilizes NO. While Paper 9 shows thiols like NAC can quench HNO effects in cardiac cells, it is unrelated to renal contrast effects and does not support NO destabilization in this context. Overall, the evidence contradicts the claim.

claim: Adult tissue-resident macrophages stem from the embryonal yolk sac and fetal liver.

naive_result.label: SUPPORT
naive_result.justification: Multiple papers support embryonic origins of adult tissue-resident macrophages. Paper 10 provides direct experimental evidence that a lineage of tissue macrophages (including Kupffer cells, Langerhans cells, and microglia) derives from the yolk sac and persists independently of HSCs. Papers 1 and 3 show that major tissue-resident macrophage populations are established before birth and self-maintain during adulthood with minimal contribution from circulating monocytes, consistent with an embryonic (yolk sac/fetal) origin. Paper 2 specifically states Kupffer cells are of fetal origin. Paper 5 (review) summarizes that most adult tissue macrophages originate during embryonic development rather than from adult monocytes, aligning with yolk sac and fetal liver contributions. No papers provided contradict this; several unrelated papers do not affect the claim.

overthinking_result.label: NOINFO
overthinking_result.justification: Only Paper 1 notes that adult Kupffer cells are of fetal origin, and Paper 5 shows tissue-resident macrophages self-maintain with minimal monocyte input. However, none of the provided papers present direct lineage evidence tracing adult tissue-resident macrophages specifically to the embryonic yolk sac and fetal liver. The remaining papers are unrelated to macrophage ontogeny. Thus, the evidence here is insufficient to verify the specific claim.

posthoc_result.label: NOINFO
posthoc_result.justification: The provided papers collectively support that many adult tissue-resident macrophages are established before birth and self-maintain with minimal input from circulating monocytes (Papers 2, 3, 4) and that at least some (e.g., Kupffer cells) are of fetal origin (Paper 1). However, none of the excerpts explicitly identify the embryonal yolk sac or fetal liver as the specific progenitor sources for adult tissue-resident macrophages. Therefore, while the evidence aligns with an embryonic/fetal origin in general, it does not directly substantiate the specific claim that adult tissue-resident macrophages stem from the embryonal yolk sac and fetal liver.

claim: Lack of clpC does not affect sporulation efficiency in Bacillus subtilis cells.
